name: zinc oxide production | zinc oxide | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/9510/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of solid zinc oxide powder. Zinc oxide, formerly also called zinc white, is a fine white powder that turns yellow when heated above 300 °C. Zinc oxide is mainly produced from residues and secondary zinc. It is used mainly in the rubber industry as a vulcanization activator or sometimes as a filler. Tires contain up to 5% zinc. Another application for zinc oxide is the use as an additive in fertilizers or in animal feed, as a dietary supplement to overcome potential zinc deficiencies. Zinc oxide is also used in the cosmetic industry for lipsticks, powders and sunscreens. Other applications of zinc oxide, such as fillers in lubricants, are of minor importance.;Three different processes are used to produce zinc oxide: about 1 – 2 % of zinc oxide is produced by the wet process, 10 – 20 % by the direct process, and the remainder by the indirect (or French) process. This dataset represents the production of zinc oxide out of secondary zinc materials by means of the indirect (or French) way. The inventory is estimated based on literature and expert judgement and represents therefore a rough estimation of the process requirements and should therefore be used only for processes where the impact of zinc oxide is not considered to be high.;References:;Hischier R., Classen M., Lehmann M. and Scharnhorst W. (2007) Life cycle inventories of Electric and Electronic Equipment: Production, Use and Disposal. ecoinvent report No. 18. Empa / Technology & Society Lab, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, 2007.;Auer, G., Woditsch, P., Westerhaus, A., Kischkewitz, J., Griebler, W.-D. and De Liedekerke, M. 2009. Pigments, Inorganic, 2. White Pigments. Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry.;Schwab, B., Ruh, A., Manthey, J. and Drosik, M. 2015. Zinc. Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry. 1–25.;Gendorf (2016) Umwelterklärung 2015, Werk Gendorf Industriepark, www.gendorf.de.

From reception of raw materials at the factory gate.

This activity ends with the production of zinc oxide. This dataset includes the input of zinc scrap (for which iron scrap is used as proxy). The consumption of air is not included. The dataset also includes the estimated energy demand and infrastructure of the plant. Solid wastes and water consumption are omitted.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Date of published literature. The electricity consumption is based on data published by the Gendorf factory that were collected between 2011 and 2015. The time period has been adjusted accordingly.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Data used has no specific geographical origin (stoichiometry). The electricity consumption is based on data from a large chemical factory located in Germany. It is assumed to be valid for this geography.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Zinc oxide is mainly produced from residues and secondary zinc by means of the indirect (or French) way. The demand for chemical purity imposed by the users means that a number of purification techniques are required. About 1 – 2 % of zinc oxide is produced by the wet process, 10 – 20 % by the direct process, and the remainder by the indirect process.;References:;Hischier R., Classen M., Lehmann M. and Scharnhorst W. (2007) Life cycle inventories of Electric and Electronic Equipment: Production, Use and Disposal. ecoinvent report No. 18. Empa / Technology & Society Lab, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, 2007.;Auer, G., Woditsch, P., Westerhaus, A., Kischkewitz, J., Griebler, W.-D. and De Liedekerke, M. 2009. Pigments, Inorganic, 2. White Pigments. Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry.;Schwab, B., Ruh, A., Manthey, J. and Drosik, M. 2015. Zinc. Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry. 1–25.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: The process data is based on literature. The electricity consumption is approximated based on data from a large chemical factory located in Germany. The process emissions are based on estimations only.

exchanges.description:
Zinc oxide formerly also called zinc white, is a fine white powder that turns yellow when heated above 300 °C.
Historically seen, Zinc oxide was a byproduct of copper smelting. Already the Romans knew this substance that they called 'cadmia'. In the 18th century, the process to produce ZnO by the combustion of metallic zinc has been discovered, and in 1840 industrial production was started by Leclaire (indirect or French process). The use of this white pigment spread rapidly. Zinc oxide replaced white lead because it had the advantage of being nontoxic, of not darkening in the presence of sulfurous gases, and of having better hiding power. In parallel the process in a roasting furnace was developed in which a grate is charged with coal and then covered with a mixture of zinc ore and coal. Here zinc is reduced by the partial combustion of the coal and reoxidized at the furnace exit (direct or American process). However, this second process is today no longer used. A third industrial production process exists but this wet process is less widely used.

flow.name: zinc oxide
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

exchanges.description:
Calculated based on literature data published by the GENDORF Chemical Park. The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. The average amount of cooling water released in the years 2015-2019 was 34408800 t per year. It was assumed that 5% of the cooling water was emitted to air during its use, therefore, to calculate the input of cooling water, the output value reported by GENDORF was scaled up by the factor 1/0.95. This equals 0.014707 m3/kg chemical produced.

References:
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit

Calculated based on literature data published by the GENDORF Chemical Park. The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. The average ouput of wastewater going to an external wastewater treatment plant in the years 2015-2019 was 5608 m3 per year. This equals 0.000002277 m3/kg chemical produced.

References:
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit

exchanges.description:
Calculated based on literature data published by the GENDORF Chemical Park. The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. To determine the emissions of water to air, the difference of all water inputs (from river, well, tap water and cooling) and outputs (wastewater, emissions to water) was calculated. The average ouput of water to air in the years 2015-2019 was 3620444 m3 per year. This equals 0.00147 m3/kg chemical produced. For more information on the other water exchanges please consult the respective exchange comment.

References:
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit

Calculated based on literature data published by the GENDORF Chemical Park. The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. The average consumption of river water in the years 2015-2019 was 22000820 t per year. However, since the cooling water is modelled as an input, the amount of river water was adjusted to avoid double counting. 55% of the input amount of cooling water was deducted from the amount of river water, as that is the share of river water versus well water. This equals 0.00096543 m3/kg chemical produced.

References:
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit

Calculated based on literature data published by the GENDORF Chemical Park. The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. The average ouput of wastewater going to an external wastewater treatment plant in the years 2015-2019 was 5608 m3 per year. This equals 0.000002277 m3/kg chemical produced.

References:
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit

exchanges.description:
Estimated value based on expert judgement. The amount of heat required for this process can vary greatly depending on the furnace design. The fuel consumption ranges from 120 L to over 250 L of heavy oil per tonne of zinc oxide (Jiyang 2009). Based on this range, an amount of 8 MJ of heat per kg of zinc oxide is assumed to be consumed. 

Reference:
Communication by Chen Jiyang (2009), Zinc oxide production by French process, https://www.finishing.com/123/73page2.shtml.

exchanges.description:
Concerning the emissions to air, due to a lack of information, it is assumed that 1% of the excess zinc input is emitted to air.

Reference:
Hischier R., Classen M., Lehmann M. and Scharnhorst W. (2007) Life cycle inventories of Electric and Electronic Equipment: Production, Use and Disposal. ecoinvent report No. 18. Empa / Technology & Society Lab, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, 2007.

flow.name: Zinc II
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description:
Calculated based on literature data published by the GENDORF Chemical Park. The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. The average consumption of well water in the years 2015-2019 was 18607480 t per year. However, since the cooling water is modelled as an input, the amount of well water was adjusted to avoid double counting. 45% of the input amount of cooling water was deducted from the amount of well water, as that is the share of well water versus river water. This equals 0.00081652 m3/kg chemical produced.

References:
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit

Calculated based on literature data published by the industry. For this activity, no information was readily available concerning infrastructure and land-use. Therefore, the infrastructure is estimated based on data from two chemical factories, the BASF site of Ludwigshafen and the chemical factory in Gendorf (which are both located in Germany), which produce a wide range of chemical substances. Based on this data, the following assumptions are made: the built area amounts to about 4.2 ha, the plant has an average output of 50'000 t/a and a lifespan of fifty years. The estimated infrastructure amount is therefore 4.00 E-10 units per kg of produced chemical.

References:
Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.
Gendorf (2000) Umwelterklärung 2000, Werk Gendorf. Werk Gendorf, Burgkirchen.

exchanges.description:
Calculated based on literature data published by the GENDORF Chemical Park. The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. The amount of water released back to the environment consists of the sum of the amount of process water treated in the internal WWTP that is then released back to the environment and the amount of cooling water released back to the environment. The average ouput of  the internal WWTP in the years 2015-2019 was 2628800 m3 and that of cooling water released back to the environment was 34408800 m3. This gives a yearly average of 37037600 m3 emissions of water to water. This equals 0.01504 m3/kg chemical produced.

References:
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit

Calculated based on literature data published by the GENDORF Chemical Park. The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. The average consumption of electricity in the years 2015-2019 was 982796751 kWh per year. This equals 0.39906 kWh/kg chemical produced.

References:
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
